Step.name: Indicators of Financial Abuse
Step.html: Unusual interest by family and other people in the person’s assets.

Step.name: Indicators of Financial Abuse
Step.html: Lack of money, especially after benefit day or unexplained or sudden withdrawals from accounts.

Step.name: Indicators of Financial Abuse
Step.html: Unexplained or sudden inability to pay bills.

Step.name: Fact
Step.html: Financial abuse is the second most reported type of abuse. The most likely people to cause harm tends to be a member of the family. Solihull Safeguarding Adults work closely with banks and building societies to raise their awareness in the prevention of financial abuse.

Step.name: Financial Abuse
Step.html: Financial abuse may include the inappropriate use, exploitation, or misappropriation of property, possessions or financial resources. This could include theft, deception, false accounting, fraud, exploitation or pressure in connection with wills, property, inheritance or financial transactions.

Step.name: Scenario
Step.html:
An elderly resident in a nursing home is visited regularly by her grandson. After the visit, she tells you how lovely he is but says he is always short of money. She tells you she always helps him out. Is this okay? Should you be worried?

Answer

It depends on the amount of money and her capacity. If it’s a small amount and she can afford to and has capacity to choose to do so then yes its ok but if she hasn’t got capacity it may not be, therefore a referral may answer those questions.
